Analyzing the surrounding area:
- To the left (8, 2) and right (8, 4) of my avatar are open ground ('.').
- Up (7, 3) is also open ground, and down (9, 3) is also open ground.
- The immediate goal is at (1, 1), which is far from my current position and there are boxes (at 1, 8; 4, 13; 4, 14; 4, 15) that I can potentially move to create a path toward the goal.

Given that there's open space available, I have several movement options. Since the avatar has not moved, I can either go left, right, up, or down. To explore further and search for possible connections to the goal, I could take a tactical step upward to begin repositioning myself towards the upper areas where the goal is located.

I will move my avatar up to (7, 3).

``` Action: 5 ``` 

By moving up, I can access more parts of the level and potentially seek a clearer path towards the goal while avoiding hazards.

Looking closely at the current state:
- Up (7, 3) is open ground ('.'), but I was previously at (7, 3) and it didn't result in any further movement.
- Left (8, 2) is open ground, and right (8, 4) is also open ground, giving me more options.

I need to make a movement that either gets me closer to the goal at (1, 1) or potentially into more advantageous positions around the boxes. Since I previously tried going up without success, perhaps moving to the left (8, 2) might be a better option to explore more of the area while keeping an eye on any paths towards the goal.

I'll execute a left movement to (8, 2).

This should allow me to evaluate the surrounding spaces more effectively and plan my next move towards the goal or to collect points efficiently.
